reasoning: First off, Amazon sits outside my circle of competence. I understand simple, wide-moat businesses like Coca-Cola or See’s Candies, but the moving parts of e-commerce algorithms and cloud-computing pricing are more complex than I care to dive into. On the moat front, AWS gives Amazon some pricing power, but the inconsistent ROE (just 4.7%) and spotty earnings growth show a moat that isn’t as durable as the ones I cherish. Management is smart—Jeff Bezos and Andy Jassy allocate capital aggressively—but they pour most owner earnings back into growth, with minimal dividends and a debt-to-equity ratio of 1.6 that gives me pause. Financially, operating margins look strong at 25%, but the weak ROIC (1.8%) and uneven earnings pattern raise red flags. The DCF pegs intrinsic value at about $585, yet shares trade well above that with virtually no margin of safety. While Amazon may prosper, I’d rather stick with proven, easy-to-understand businesses at fair prices than overpay for complexity. No regrets passing on this one.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 4.7%; High debt to equity ratio of 1.6; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 440.9% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 3/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 25.0%) indicate pricing power moat

book_value_analysis.details: Good book value per share growth pattern; Excellent book value CAGR: 23.0%

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (7.3%, 5y), Stage 2 (3.7%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
